ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PREMATURE SCHOOL LETTERS
(Introduction of compulsory training)


    1. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) what was the number of premature school leavers by age group and educational level in 1983; (b) how many of them failed to enrol for vocational and technical classes in VITB institutes under its automatic registration scheme; and (c) whether his Ministry will reconsider the need to introduce compulsory training for all premature school leavers to ensure that entrants into the labour market are adequately prepared for further skill upgrading in industry.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of premature school leavers at both primary and secondary school levels in 1983 is similar to that in the year before. There were 2,027 premature primary school leavers in 1983. Compared with 8,900 in 1978, the year before streaming was introduced, the dropout rate has gone down by nearly 41/2 times.

    At secondary level, 2,281 pupils dropped out of school last year. Compared with the rate in 1980, the year before streaming was introduced at secondary level, the reduction is nearly four-fold. The overall saving has been 13,600 pupils who would otherwise have dropped out. At this rate, the result of our streaming policy is that nearly one-third of a cohort is saved from dropping out each year.

    Last year, the automatic registration scheme was tried out on a big scale for the first time for the pupils who failed the PSLE and had to leave school. Out of the 2,030 pupils posted to VITB, 75.6% of them have enrolled in VITB courses. The scheme is being extended to pupils who drop out of school at other levels. For comparison, the success rate in attracting premature school leavers to VITB a few years ago was only 20%. VITB has taken follow-up action to contact the 25% who failed to enrol at

Column: 1082

VITB. The main reason why many did not enrol is that they have found employment.

    I do not think there is any need at the moment to introduce compulsory training for all premature school leavers.

COST OF EDUCATION
(Particulars)


    2. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) what was the cost of education over the last five years for each student (i) at the primary, secondary and tertiary levels; (ii) by field of study at tertiary level; and (iii) the percentage increase against 1959 and adjusted for inflation; and (b) how much subsidy in 1983 was given to the education of each student at these levels so that parents can have a better idea of the amount of investment spent on the education of our children.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answers to the hon. Member's question would require several tables. I would be happy to provide them to him later. I will instead highlight a few of the points raised by his question.

    Over the past five years, the recurrent cost of education at all levels has doubled. The main increase has been due to salary adjustments.

    In 1983, the cost for educating a child in primary school was $1,255. At secondary and junior college levels, the costs were $2,067 and $2,974 respectively. Since school fees are very low, school education is highly subsidized by the state. .

    At the VITB and Polytechnics, the average costs to train a student are $4,400 and $5,800 per annum respectively. At the university, the average cost is $14,200 per annum. This varies widely, ranging from $8,000 for Accountancy and Business Administration students to $43,300 for the Medical students. Again, as the fees charged by the institutions are fairly low, the cost is highly subsidized.

    In 1959, it cost $125 per annum to provide a place for a child in primary

Column: 1083

school and $4,600 per annum to educate a student at the then University of Malaya. These costs have, of course, gone up over the years with inflation.

CAGE FISHING AND SUPPLY OF POULTRY, VEGETABLES AND PORK


    3. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (a) what is the total number of licences issued by the Primary Production Department for cage fishing to date; (b) to what extent this type of fishing has contributed towards meeting the local demand; and (c) whether the Department has any plan to ensure the constant supply of poultry, vegetables and pork at stable and reasonable prices.

     The First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Primary Production Department has so far issued 63 licences for marine cage net fish farms covering a total sea area of 35 hectares. These farms are located off the coast of Pulau Ubin, Serangoon, Punggol and Lim Chu Kang.

    The estimated annual production of fish from these farms is about 1,500 tonnes or 2% of the total estimated annual consumption of 72,500 tonnes. Thus, marine cage net fish culture's contribution towards meeting the demand for fish has been small. The extent to which the contribution will increase depends on the fish farmers themselves. Marine cage net fish culture is capital intensive and, for this reason, has been used primarily to farm high-valued fish and prawns for sale to restaurants and hotels.

    I have outlined in reply to a previous question the Government's current thinking on pig farming. The Government's policy is to encourage liberal trade practices which will facilitate the import of food supplies from the cheapest source. What applies to pig farmers applies equally to producers of poultry and vegetables. They must compete in order to survive.

    4. Mr J.B.      The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, professional visit passes are only issued to foreigners on specific short-term engagements ranging from one day to few months. Statistics are not kept according to the format requested, as the numbers involved are small. Professional visit passes are usually issued to singers. stage performers, dancers, magicians, concert musicians and participants of professional seminars. In 1983, 5,392 passes were issued.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, would the Minister tell the House whether any firm in the oil industry, manufacturing industry, banking or law firm has ever applied for these passes?

If he asks a question about "professional visit passes", we must assume, by any reasonable construction, that he means professional visit passes. If he wants to ask a separate question on employment passes,

     Dr Koh Lip Lin (Nee Soon): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head T be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead TA-01 Object Group 1100 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, the purpose of moving this amendment is to ask the Minister whether he would review certain aspects of the practices of the Resettlement Department which deals with the clearance and resettlement of lands and people affected by public projects, such as new towns, highways and reservoir catchments. Nee Soon is one of the constituencies which is very much affected by these projects. I have received numerous petitions and complaints on matters related to resettlement. I would be grateful if the Minister would consider taking measures to improve the following matters.

    First, planning of clearance and resettlement. Often there are cases where lands are urgently required by the authority and the occupants are chased out in a very short time. There are also cases where people are informed that they are to be resettled soon and yet after a number of years they are still waiting. For this group of people their future is very uncertain. They are not able to develop their farm or business because they may be asked to

Column: 1086

quit any time. Meanwhile, they can only wait and watch the prices of HDB flats and shops going up each year. There are cases where a whole village has been resettled leaving only one or two families, and these families become isolated and have to worry about security, transportation problems and so on. They appeal to the Resettlement Department for early resettlement but usually they are not successful because the one or two houses happen to fall outside the lines drawn on the maps of the Resettlement Department.

    There are also cases where private lands are acquired by HDB. Instead of trying to resettle these residents and owners quickly, HDB's Land Management Unit starts to collect very high TOL rentals at commercial rates. My question is: If the lands are urgently needed, why are these people not resettled immediately? If the lands are not required urgently, why bother to acquire them so early? In general, I would like to ask the Minister to ensure that there is better coordination among the various departments, such as the Resettlement Department, the Engineering Department and the Lands Management Unit.

    The second point I would like to raise is about the assistance given to people who have lost their means of livelihood because of resettlement. In his written answer to a question raised by the hon. Member for Ayer Rajah in the sitting of this House on 12th March 1984, the Minister said that there were very few people who were resettled who found difficulty in adjusting to the life-style in HDB estates. He also said that farmers who wished to go into business were given priority for HDB shops, industrial workshops, hawker stalls or kiosks. I beg to disagree with him. During my five years' service as Member for Nee Soon I have written at least several hundreds, if not, thousands of letters to HDB on behalf of people who were affected by resettlement, to request for priority allocation of hawker stalls, shops and kiosks. I have to inform the Minister, that other than a few cases where HDB Resettlement Department had deemed to qualify for priority allocation, almost

Column: 1087

all the requests were unsuccessful. Apparently, these people are not as happy as the Minister thinks they ought to be.

    Sir, I would like to urge the Minister to reconsider the request of the hon. Member for Ayer Rajah to set up a research unit to find out what has happened to those who have lost their means of livelihood because of resettlement. I am not referring to the resettled squatters who live in the villages and work outside. I am referring to those who live in the village and who make their livelihood in the village. I am sure my colleagues from the rural constituencies will support my request.

    The third point I would like to raise is about farm compensation. There are not many farmers left in Singapore now. Most of them are not young men and will have difficulty in finding a livelihood after resettlement. They should be adequately compensated for. In the past few years, farmers as well as my parliamentary colleagues have requested that the compensation for the farm licence be pegged to the price of a three-room flat. The request was not acceded to. I would like to take this opportunity to make the request again.
2.45 pm

    The compensation of fruit trees is another topic which has caused a great deal of unhappiness. Before December 1982, fruit trees were compensated by the number of trees. After that date, a coiling was introduced to set the upper limit per hectare of land. As a result, quite a few farmers who had signed agreements for their compensation had their compensation reduced, some as much as 60%. To these farmers, this is an act of breach of promise by the Government. However, the Resenlement Department claimed that they had to do this because many farmers were planting big numbers of small tress to increase their compensation. It may be true that some farmers had planted an excess number of trees just to cheat the Government. But many of them resorted to this practice because the compensation they would get would be too little because

Column: 1088

their big trees were not fairly compensated for.

    I would like to ask the Minister a few questions. Why was compensation for fruit trees based on the number of trees before 1982? Did the Resenlement Department think of the possibility of abuse then? Is the Minister aware that the present rates of compensation for fruit trees are unreasonable and do not represent the economic value of the trees?

    To illustrate what I mean, let me explain how the trees are compensated. Fruit trees are classified into various categories. They are also classified into various heights. Trees below one metre in height are classified as small trees. Those from one to three metres are medium trees, and those above three metres are big trees. The rates also vary for each category and height. This looks great on paper, but it is not practical at all because the same yardstick for height is used for all fruit trees, regardless of the kind of fruit trees. This is most unreasonable. For example, a three-metre coconut tree is classified as a big tree. Anyone who has seen a coconut tree knows that a three-metre coconut tree is a young tree and not a big tree. And a full grown lime tree (suan kan su) of two-metre height is classified as a medium tree. Anyone who has cultivated a lime tree knows that a two-metre lime tree is a full grown tree. I sometimes wonder whether those who were responsible for drafting the regulations had ever seen a coconut tree or a lime tree in their life.

    For a given category of trees, the compensation rate for a small tree is usually too high, and that for a big tree the compensation rate is grossly undervalued. $156 for a big durian tree is an example of an extreme undervaluation of a tree. It is, therefore, no surprise that farmers had to resort to planting small trees so that they could cover the losses due to the under-compensation of their big trees.

    I would like to urge the Minister to review the rates of compensation for fruit trees as well as the farm related items, such as fish tanks, chicken sheds and so on. I hope this time those who are appointed to do the revision are people

Column: 1089

who have some common sense and know, ledge about farms and fruit trees.

    Sir, I beg to move.

     Encik Saidi Haji Shariff: Sir, I have an amendment under Subhead TG-02 on the same subject. Can I speak now? It is amendment (7).

     The Chairman: All right.

     Encik Saidi Haji Shariff: Sir, the quotation "The buck stops here" should be adopted as a motto by a few Government Departments that exercise jurisdiction over the question of resettlement and the maintenance of the area that is undergoing resettlement. The way the buck has been passed around from department to department does not endear them to residents who, after the traumatic experience of being told that they would be resettled, have to stay behind until new homes are actually allocated to them. As a living example, I refer to the residents of Kaki Bukit Constituency who are affected by resettlement. No one disputed the necessity of resettlement within the context of national interest and national development. What caused some unhappiness among residents was the low standard of upkeep of the estate while the slow process of resettling people was under way. Thus, it was not rare to find residents having to share their abode with mosquitoes, snakes and flies. Whenever it poured, unwholesome lakes surfaced. Roads waiting for expansion stood in the meantime in glaring need of repairs. Faulty street lamps dimmed to add to the darkness. When the Citizens' Consultative Committee initiated remedial action, action was often deferred because no relevant department seemed to be in direct charge, leading to a wastage of time and lower quality of life. The real culprit behind all these is that the buck has been passed.

    As a remedial measure, may I propose that in future resettlement cases, whatever department is ultimately responsible for the proper maintenance of the various

Column: 1090

physical facilities and the environment itself, the Resettlement Department be given the overall responsibility to oversee the situation so that no time is wasted in soliciting the necessary response from the departments concerned. To centralize authority in this way is good as it ensures that remedial measures are forthcoming without much undue delay.

    I wish to dwell a little now on another aspect of resenlement which has created some confusion and unhappiness among residents. Often they have to wait for a period of two to three years before they can be allocated their own flats as the flats are not yet available. This is so in the case of residents in Kaki Bukit Constituency who are affected by resenlement. Within such a time frame many unexpected things could have happened, arid often did happen. There were deaths, marriages and births. These subtractions and additions to the families affected their qualification for flats. Besides there was always the fear of yet another price rise. In fact, people affected by resenlement are allocated flats at a certain price while the remainder are allocated flats at different prices.

    To alleviate their anxiety, may I propose that the time frame be shortened and the actual price of flats be pegged to the actual cut-off date when the affected residents receive notices to quit. Furthermore, resettlement should not be announced and notice to quit the premises should not be given unless there are sufficient flats available for allocation to those affected within the shortest time possible.

    Considering the healthy state of our economy as presented by the Budget Statement, enabling the Government to grant tax rebates and enhanced tax reliefs, it is perhaps appropriate that the Ministry review the resettlement compensation rates again and increase it in view of the announcement that the price of flats will be increased again this year.

    Sir, I am not flogging a dead horse. Whatever happened at Kaki Bukit perhaps

Column: 1091

could not be undone as it is in the lapse of resettlement. In response to my appeal in this House on 23rd March 1981, the Minister stated:

    'The HDB will consider the retention of these features if they are consistent with the over all development plan of the area.'

I am curious to know what are these features to be retained. I am also curious to know why there are still about 100 residents or families, according to my grassroots feedback report, who have not been allocated flats even though the Minister on 23rd October 1981, stated:

    '1,425 families have to be resettled to make way for the development of Kaki Bukit Estate. Resenlement of all affected families is .expected to be completed by 1983.'

    The Hon. Minister could perhaps give the present state of affairs. Anyway, I believe most residents affected owe a debt of gratitude to those Resettlement Department officers who have done their best to ensure a smooth and less painful removal to their new homes. However, the experience learnt could be worthwhile if the object lessons learnt here are used to benefit other estates yet to be resettled. Our Prime Minister has said that we should make resealement less painful and be more humane.

     The Chairman: Mr Jeyaretnam, you have an amendment on resettlement too. Would you like to speak now?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Do you want me to move the amendment?

     The Chairman: There is no need for you to move the amendment.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: All right, Mr Speaker, Sir. But I might not withdraw my motion on this.

    Sir, this question that I want to speak on now, that is, resettlement, has already been touched upon by two other speakers. We have heard from the last speaker about the statement made by the Prime Minister;

Column: 1092

it is not just the Prime Minister; we have heard other Ministers too mouthing these sentiments in their Sunday walkabouts when they are confronted by residents to whom resettlement has become a searing experience and who are wrecked with torment and anxiety.

    Sir, what I do want to ask the Minister is this. Does his Ministry and the Government accept in principle the responsibility to house people who are being rooted out of their homes? It is no good trying to equate yourself with the private landlord. This is a Government carrying out its programme, and in pursuance of that programme, it roots out people who have been living in their homes. Does the Government accept its responsibility to everyone who is living in houses in the area which the Government proposes to resettle to make way for new development? I should like to know that from the Minister. To me the answer is obvious.

    I have spoken last year on this subject and I touched upon the case of a man in my constituency in Anson in Kampong Bahru area. He has been denied any resenlement simply because, again we come back to the same question which I raised yesterday, his wife is not a permanent resident although he is a Singapore citizen.
3.00 pm

    So we go on, ding-dong. The poor man does not know what he is going to do. He works for the Ministry of the Environment. What I would like to know from the Minister is: what are you going to do about him? Are you going to put him out on the road, or are you going to house him when the time comes?

    I wish to ask the same question about one or two other families in Miri Road. There we have a family of a father, mother and a little boy. They have been told that they are not eligible for resettlement because apparently they moved in after the cut-off date. But, as I mentioned pre-

Column: 1093

viously, the cut-off date was never announced by any notice put up in these areas. I know and it is no good telling me that it was in the Gazette somewhere. It was never brought to their attention when they moved in, and they have been living there. What are you going to do about them? Are you going to put them out on the street? I would like an answer to that. There is not just one family, there is one other family in Miri Road. They told me they cannot move, and I am afraid I have told them, "You don't move. You are entitled to be resettled by the Government if the Government is acquiring the land for its development purposes." So they are waiting to know what the answer will be.

    May I move on to another area which is not within my constituency, and that is, the Craig Road people? Mr Speaker, Sir, there has been some publicity about this and there was only recently an article in the Far Eastern Economic Review drawing attention to a man who is still squatting on the pavement. But what I find incredulous about this is that the Resettlement Department should hide behind the fact that the private owner of the property had obtained a court order to evict them. The private owner may not have a moral responsibility for the persons living in the premises. But I should hope that this Government and the Ministry of National Development have a moral responsibility.

    What I find shocking is this, that the Ministry of National Development has paid the owner enhanced compensation so as to relieve itself of its obligation to the tenants. And then it says, "Well, we've paid the owner enhanced compensation. So we can't now give the tenants any premises." That seems to me to be scandalous. It is an evasion of the Ministry's responsibility to those persons. How did the Ministry come to pay the owner enhanced compensation without first making sure from him that the tenants who were living there would be adequately housed and that he would, in fact, give vacant possession, not just a court order, but that he would make provision for the tenants and would give vacant possession? As a result of the Ministry paying the owner enhanced compensation and saying it is not the Ministry's baby, it is

Column: 1094

his baby, you have families living on the pavement. Honestly, as I said, I find this a shocking and scandalous behaviour on the part of a Government to its citizens and to its people to whom it owes some obligation. Are they not entitled to be housed?

    Sir, I would like the Minister to consider this and let us know in this House today, first of all, whether his Ministry will accept squarely the responsibility upon it and not hide behind rules and say, "These are the rules. That man has got a court order. We've paid him enhanced compensation. So the rules say we can't do anything about the tenants."

    May I remind the Minister and the Government that rules are not sacrosanct but people are? Rules are made for people, not people for rules. And if rules work injustice, work inequity and are harsh, then rules have to be changed. They do not remain inviolate and immutable. Rules are made by us for our welfare and so they have to be changed if they are found to be working injustice, hardship, suffering on our people.

    I should like to know whether the Minister would answer these three questions.

     The Chairman: Dr Augustine Tan and Mr Selvadurai are not here.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe (Geylang Serai): Mr Speaker, Sir, my amendment is amendment (4). One of the issues which I would like to speak on is Resettlement. Can I speak now?

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe: One of the issues is on resettlement. So I would like to speak again when amendment (4) comes up.

     The Chairman: Then you had better speak later on. Mr Teh.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to answer the Member for Anson first. The Member for Anson has asked the question whether Government accepts the responsibility to house the people affected by resettlement. My answer is that Government accepts the

Column: 1095

responsibility to house the people affected by resettlement, but only for those people who are qualified to be resettled.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Under your rules. Here we go again!

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: This is very simple. In an area under resettlement, the people will get priority for alternative accommodation like houses, shops and other premises.
